Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A New Twist on Muscle Contraction
Award.AbstractNarration:
The sliding filament theory is widely accepted as a useful model of muscle contraction in isolated preparations. However, the theory fails to account for critically important characteristics of muscle function. Despite decades of work, a predictive model of muscle force during natural movements remains elusive. The researchers will test the hypothesis that important properties of muscle can be explained by the winding filament hypothesis. The proposed work has significant potential to inform our understanding of how neural activation and applied forces together determine in vivo muscle force. Results from the research will be integrated into graduate and/or undergraduate courses at Denison University (RUI-eligible), Northwestern University, and Northern Arizona University. In addition, the research team will leverage programs at Denison University and Northern Arizona University for recruiting under-represented participants in research. Results will be disseminated to broad audiences through standard mechanisms of publication and diverse public media, as well as participation in interdisciplinary conferences in the areas of engineering, biomechanics, and physiology.

The researchers will use the mdm mouse to test predictions of the winding filament hypothesis. The winding hypothesis claims that, in addition to the thin filaments, titin is activated by Ca2+, and that cross-bridges not only translate but also rotate the thin filaments, storing elastic energy in PEVK titin during isometric force development. Due to constraints of sarcomere geometry on titin activation and winding, the hypothesis makes unique quantitative predictions about the effects of stimulation and length changes on muscle force. By including different muscles in the proposed studies, the researchers can determine whether naturally occurring variation in titin structure and function contributes to activation- and length-dependent muscle properties (e.g., doublet potentiation and force depression/enhancement). The experiments will test whether titin activation and winding, alone or in combination, can account for observed muscle forces by comparing experimental results to model predictions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sliding filament theory is widely accepted as a useful model of muscle contraction in isolated preparations. However, the theory fails to account for critically important characteristics of muscle function. Despite decades of work, a predictive model of muscle force during natural movements remains elusive. The goal of this project was to test the hypothesis that important properties of muscle, which have defied explanation for decades, can be explained by titin, an activation-dependent spring in active muscle. The hypothesis claims that, in addition to the thin filaments, titin is activated by calcium release in active muscle which enables binding of titin to actin. The specific aims were: 1) to investigate the force-extension properties of domains of titin in soleus and extensor digitorum muscles from wild type and mdm mice using immuno-flourescence labeling and other methods to measure parameters for msucle models; 2) to measure muscle force in a variety of ex vivo experiments and to use data from these experiments for validation and testing of muscle models; and 3) to develop and test new muscle models that include a role for titin in active muscle. The results of Aim 1 have shown that titin binds to actin in the presence of calcium, with higher rupture forces and lower off rates than at lower calcium concentrations. The results demonstrate that titin is a tunable activation-dependent spring in muscle and provide parameters for muscle models that include a role for titin in mechanics of active muscle. The results of Aim 2 provided a variety of experimental data for validating and testing muscle models. The results of Aim 3 that these muscle models based on titin significantly out-perform standard Hill models in predicting muscle force in ex vivo experiments. The results further demonstrate that titin-based models perform well at predicting in vivo muscle forces in guinea fowl during treadmill running with obstacle perturbations. These simulation results are consistent with previous studies showing that titin-based models can be used as algorithms for forward prediction of ankle torque during walking at variable speed and stair climbing in a robotic foot-ankle prosthesis. Many observable behaviors of muscle, including force enhancement and depression, have been difficult to explain based on conventional muscle models that include cross bridges, collagen, isometric force-length and isotonic force-velocity properties of muscle. Force enhancement and depression are consistent with the presence of an activation-dependent spring in active muscle, namely titin. The results have fundamental implications for understanding the biomechanics and control of human and animal movements. Muscle models based on titin have been used to develop control algorithms for wearable robotic devices including prostheses and exoskeletons. By emulating muscle properties, the algorithms show demonstrably greater adaptation across tasks than commercially available engineered alternatives. In terms of broader impacts, the proposed work has significantly informed the understanding of how neural activation and applied forces together determine muscle forces during natural movements. This understanding is likely to lead to improved neuro-musculoskeletal models with wide applications in biomechanics, neuroscience and medicine, and may also provide insights into causes and possibly cures for a variety of neuro-musculo-skeletal diseases. The new muscle models have the potential to inspire the design of a new generation of actuators and prostheses that possess the adaptability and energy efficiency displayed by animal muscles. Results and hypotheses on which they are based were integrated into graduate courses at Northern Arizona University (NAU). The project contributed to three completed M.S. degrees, two completed Ph.D. degrees, and provided interdisciplinary research experiences for one postdoctoral scholar, three additional doctoral students, one additional M.S. student and two undergraduate students. One undergraduate student received a Goldwater Scholarship based in part on his participation in this project.
